name: Herbal Chinese Medicine (Chinese Herbal Medicine)
summary: Formulas derived from Traditional Chinese Medicine (TCM) combining multiple herbs and natural substances to address pattern-based diagnoses and support symptom relief and functional balance.
description: Chinese herbal medicine is a core component of Traditional Chinese Medicine (TCM) that uses multi-herb formulas tailored to an individual’s pattern of disharmony (e.g., Qi, Blood, Yin/Yang, organ meridian patterns). Classical formulas are modified by licensed practitioners to match presentation and stage of illness. From a biomedical perspective, Chinese herbs contain diverse phytochemicals that may exert anti-inflammatory, analgesic, antimicrobial, immunomodulatory, or gastrointestinal effects. Evidence is strongest for a limited number of conditions and specific standardized products; quality and safety depend on sourcing, correct diagnosis, dosing, and avoidance of herb–drug interactions.

practice_styles: Classical formulas (Shang Han Lun, Jin Gui Yao Lue)
Granules, decoctions, pills, tinctures, topical liniments
delivery_methods: Individually compounded formulas by licensed practitioners
treatment_duration: Chronic conditions: 1–3 months with reassessment; maintenance as needed
metadata.training_required: Licensed acupuncturist/TCM herbalist or physician with accredited herbal training; knowledge of pharmacognosy and herb–drug interactions required.
metadata.regulatory_status: Regulation varies by country; many products treated as dietary supplements. Quality control and contamination standards differ across manufacturers.

primary_indications: Allergic rhinitis and common cold support
contraindications: Absolute: Known allergy to formula components; pregnancy for formulas containing contraindicated herbs; severe hepatic or renal impairment without medical supervision; concurrent use with interacting drugs when unsafe.

Relative: Anticoagulation therapy (risk with Salvia miltiorrhiza, Angelica sinensis, etc.); antihypertensives, antidiabetics (potential potentiation); autoimmune disease on immunosuppressants; infants/toddlers without pediatric expertise.
clinical_metadata.safety_profile: Generally well tolerated when prescribed by trained clinicians using reputable sources. Risks include herb–drug interactions, misidentification/adulteration, contamination (heavy metals, pesticides), and organ toxicity with certain herbs or improper dosing.
clinical_metadata.evidence_level: Mixed. Moderate evidence for some standardized formulas (e.g., allergic rhinitis, IBS subtypes, dysmenorrhea) and specific single herbs/extracts; heterogeneous quality overall.

sections.text: TCM theory frames herbs as restoring balance of Qi, Blood, Yin/Yang, and organ systems via tailored formulas (e.g., tonifying, dispersing, clearing heat, resolving dampness). Biomedically, herbs provide multiple phytochemicals that may modulate inflammatory pathways (COX/LOX), neurotransmission (GABAergic, serotonergic), smooth muscle tone, the gut–brain axis and microbiota, and immune responses.

sections.preparation: Comprehensive evaluation including TCM history, tongue and pulse exam; review medications, allergies, pregnancy status, and lab history (liver/kidney function if needed).
procedure: Select base classical formula aligned to pattern (e.g., Xiao Yao San for Liver Qi constraint, Si Jun Zi Tang for spleen Qi deficiency).
Modify with adjunct herbs to target symptoms/stage (e.g., add anti-phlegm, move Blood, calm Shen).
Determine form (decoction, granules, pills) and dosing schedule.
Provide safety counseling (interactions, expected timeline, when to stop).
Reassess every 1–4 weeks; adjust formula as pattern evolves.
sections.duration: Acute: 1–3 weeks; chronic: 4–12+ weeks with taper or maintenance.
sections.total_treatment_time: Varies by condition and response; periodic labs if clinically indicated.

items: Classical formulas (e.g., Xiao Yao San, Si Ni San, Liu Wei Di Huang Wan, Gui Zhi Tang)
Condition-focused patents (e.g., Yu Ping Feng San for immune support, Ban Xia Hou Po Tang for globus)
Topicals (Die Da Jiu liniments for bruises/sprains)

immediate: Symptom soothing (some GI and sleep formulas)
short_term: Reduced GI discomfort, improved nasal symptoms, better sleep quality, moderated menstrual pain
long_term: Improved functional resilience and symptom stability; reduced relapse frequency

common: GI upset, taste/odor aversion, mild dizziness
rare: Herb-induced liver injury with certain products or contamination

absolute: Pregnancy for formulas/herbs contraindicated in pregnancy (e.g., certain blood-moving or purgative herbs)
Severe hepatic/renal disease without physician oversight
special_considerations: Source only from GMP-compliant suppliers; avoid products with animal/endangered species.
Check for heavy metals, pesticides, adulterants (lab COAs).
Document and monitor for herb–drug interactions.

ideal_candidates: Patients seeking integrative support for functional conditions
Those with recurrent symptom patterns responsive to TCM approaches
Individuals able to adhere to daily dosing and follow-up
screening_required: Baseline liver/kidney function when clinically indicated

concurrent_therapies: Dietary and lifestyle counseling (per TCM and biomedical guidance)
Mind–body practices (acupuncture, tai chi/qigong, CBT for IBS/insomnia)
lifestyle_recommendations: Anti-inflammatory diet patterns matched to tolerance
Avoid alcohol when starting new formulas; limit caffeine if sensitive

sections.typical_session_cost: Consult $80–$200; herbs $30–$120 per 2–4 weeks depending on form and dose
sections.insurance_coverage: Typically not covered in the U.S.; some plans cover practitioner consults under acupuncture benefits

items: Use pattern-based diagnosis; avoid one-size-fits-all patents for complex cases.
Start low, go slow—especially in polypharmacy or frail patients.
Educate on signs to stop and seek care (rash, jaundice, dark urine, severe GI upset).
Prefer plant-only, ethically sourced formulas; avoid endangered animal/mineral products.
Coordinate with the patient’s medical team for safety and outcome tracking.

seo.description: Overview of Chinese herbal medicine: indications, mechanisms, protocols, safety, interactions, and evidence for conditions like IBS, allergic rhinitis, dysmenorrhea, and insomnia.
